text: 16th May 1982
You are Andrei Berezkinov, a Soviet cosmonaut.
Along with your crewmate, Valente Lebedevsky, you are the first team to man the Soviet space station...
SALYUT-7
Your mission is to activate this new space station, conduct various biological studies and use the station's instruments to observe astronomical phenomena.

Having docked with Salyut 3 days ago (13th May 1982), you and Lebedevsky have just finished bringing the stain fully online, initializing its life support systems, communications, power systems, and scientific equipment.

You are now required to conduct a comprehensive series of inspections and checks to ensure that all systems are functioning correctly and that the station is ready for long-term habitation and operations.
Are you up to the job?
<span class='speaker'>Lebdevsky:<span> Good morning, Andrei. Are you ready to start the air quality checks for today?

option1.buttonText: Good morning, Valente. Of course, let's begin.

option2.buttonText: I can't wait! Let's get started!

text: Lebedevsky: Alright. Let's start with the oxygen levels
Lebdevsky: I'll check the readings from the Oxygen Generation System, you take a look at CO2 removal.
Lebdevsky: Check the Lithium Hydroxide canisters, the Co2 levels, and the system logs, in that order.
Lebdevsky: Come and see me when you're done.
Lebedevsky: Cool your jets, spaceman. We'll be here for long enough.
It's best not to rush things.
Idle minds unravel fast up here.

option1.buttonText: You're right. If there's one thing we have plenty of, it's time!

option2.buttonText: We have more than enough experiments to keep us occupied.

option3.buttonText: I am aware of the mental toll space travel can take.

text: Lebedevsky: What's the matter, comrade? Still struggling with the space sickness?

option2.buttonText: No, no, just a little tired. I'm ready!

text: Lebedevsky: Exactly. We're the first crew to be stationed here. We need to make sure we look after the place.
Slow and steady, that's the pace up here.
But look who I'm talking to. You've been with the agency for long enough.
What's it been, 10 years now?
Lebedevsky: You speak some truth there, comrade.
But before we even begin thinking about experiments we will have to check the ECLS, power systems, radio comms and data transmission, radiation shielding, back up systems...
The list goes on.

But look who I'm talking to. You've been with the agency for long enough.
What's it been, 10 years now?
